item.title: Skyman, 2019 - ★★
item.description: The owls were not what they seemed.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: The Things With The Glowing Green Eyes
item.letterboxd:filmTitle: The Things With The Glowing Green Eyes
item.description: Watched on Saturday April 24, 2021.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Urban Legends: Bloody Mary, 2005 - ★½
item.description: I had a thoroughly dull time revisiting this one.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Urban Legends: Final Cut, 2000 - ★★★★
item.description:
Once again, glorious nonsense.
The World's most unlikely film school, with its aeroplane soundstage and slasher movie syllabus, more expositionary dialogue than you can shake a stick it, a ridiculous and contrived plot, and a film that seems to think it is following in the footsteps of Hitchcock when it's closer to Graduation Day.
I love it so much.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Urban Legend, 1998 - ★★★½
item.description: I will never tire of this delightful nonsense.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Female Trouble, 1974 - ★★★★
item.description:
Happy birthday John Waters!
Female Trouble is wild, disgusting, hilarious, and ridiculously entertaining.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Flash Gordon, 1980 - ★★★★
item.description:
Much to my surprise this was the first time I've seen Flash Gordon from start to finish. Better late than never?

What a fantastic looking film! The recent 4K release looks superb. Great costuming and a smashing ensemble cast, though with the amount of scenery chewing going on it's amazing that the sets survived filming.
Ming's wedding vows are pretty amazing. Speaking of amazing, Ornella Muti.
The plot could have been written by an eight year old, but everything else is so bold, bright, brash and beguiling that it hardly matters.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: That's Sexploitation!, 2013 - ★★★
item.description:
More of a visual history of Sexploitation than anything in depth or probing.
A bit like eating an entire birthday cake - or maybe cheesecake would be more fitting? - by yourself in one sitting, the novelty of plentiful nudity wears off over the two and a bit hours run time, and a few more contributers would have been nice.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Murders in the Rue Morgue, 1932 - ★★★
item.description:
Bela Lugosi does some very entertaining scenery chewing as a mad doctor, some classic Universal atmosphere covers up the gaps left by studio meddling, and resemblances to the Edgar Allan Poe story are slim.
Not top tier stuff, but an enjoyable hour and change.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Deadlier Than the Male, 1967 - ★★½
item.description:
A slight but fun supermarket value brand version of James Bond.
Johnson's Bulldog Drummond is no Sean Connery, but the female assassins are fab, it's all quite stylish, and decently entertaining.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Dance with the Devil, 1997 - ★★★★½
item.description:
Bananas.
That's the first word I can think of to describe this.
A riot of colour, sex, violence, weirdness and humour.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Stop Making Sense, 1984 - ★★★★★
item.description: It's perfect.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: The Ghastly Ones, 1968 - ★★½
item.description:
I am here for Colin the murderous hunchback.

Not a good film, but curiously enjoyable.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Capricorn One, 1977 - ★★★½
item.description:
Highly entertaining, so long as you are willing to go with the flow and ignore the various absurdities that crop up.

Maybe it's just as well that OJ never made it to Mars.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Magdalena, Possessed by the Devil, 1974 - ★★★
item.description:
Absolutely bonkers German Exorcist rip off.
Sleazy as heck, totally nonsense with some of the best worst dialogue I've ever heard.
In no way a good film, but ridiculously enjoyable and entertaining.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Who Can Kill a Child?, 1976 - ★★★★½
item.description:
Who Can Kill a Child? does not mess around with the opening, kicking off with actual footage of the effects of war on children. It's a harrowing way to start off a horror film, but an effective one, knocking the viewer sideways before getting into the film itself.

The film is a sun drenched nightmare, a holidaying couple picking the wrong island to go and visit.
This is a film that's big on atmosphere, with a sense of dread, unease and wrongness throughout, at odds with the sunshine and scenery.

This is a top tier entry in the Killer Kids canon.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Splatter University, 1984 - ★½
item.description: Loads of blood doesn't stop this being pish.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: The City of the Dead, 1960 - ★★★★
item.description:
Christopher Lee plus witches plus enough fog to sink a fleet of ships equals a film I enjoyed immensely.

Weirdest trivia of the day was learning the film was partially financed by Nottingham Forest Football Club.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: The Addiction, 1995 - ★★★★
item.description:
Once again I'm not convinced this heavily metaphorical vampire film is *really* about vampires.
Great though.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Hail Satan?, 2019 - ★★★★
item.description: Well made, thoughtful and often very funny. Hail Satan.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Baba Yaga, 1973 - ★★★½
item.description:
Don't you just hate how comic book films all follow the same formula?
Surrealism, witchcraft, gratuitous nudity, BDSM and a swinging jazz score.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Bill & Ted's Bogus Journey, 1991 - ★★★★
item.description:
All Battle of the Bands competition are rigged scams, but this one really takes the cake.
In addition to being 85% magnificent, Bogus Journey is also responsible for me buying my first Kiss record and my first Evan Dorkin comics, so it gets points back there to balance the ones lost for the very 90s homophobic slurs.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Beaster Day: Here Comes Peter Cottonhell, 2014 - ★
item.letterboxd:filmTitle: Beaster Day: Here Comes Peter Cottonhell
item.description:
We'd all have been better off if this had been a short film.
Laughably bad in every way, which is fun for a while, but the novelty wears off quick.
Happy Easter.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Streets of Fire, 1984 - ★★★★
item.description:
Streets of Fire was an impulse purchase and a blind watch based on some positive chatter from some Letterboxd friends, and rarely has that worked out so well.

This was an absolute delight, a total mishmash of genres and styles, with remarkable cheesy dialogue. It really shouldn't have worked, yet here I am, fresh from watching, with a big dumn smile on my face.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure, 1989 - ★★★★
item.description: I will forever laugh at Beeth Oven.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Arcade, 1993 - ★½
item.description:
Remember beloved children's virtual reality TV show Knightmare?
Good, wasn't it?
Go watch an old episode of that again instead of this.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Ms .45, 1981 - ★★★★½
item.description:
Thana had a really bad day.
Abel Ferrara delivers another grubby, dirty story from New York, that stands head and shoulders above similarly themed exploitation films.
Zoe Lund is incredibly, without saying a word.
Surprisingly funky soundtrack.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: The Taking of Deborah Logan, 2014 - ★★★
item.description:
Neatly effective found footage/possession movie, with a good few well placed jump scares, and some well used effects.

Shout out to Mia for continuing to make her Alzheimer's documentary as the shit clearly hits the fan around her.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Megan Is Missing, 2011 - ½
item.description: Nope.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Where Evil Dwells, 1985 - ★★★★
item.description:
A grainy, black and white, surreal nightmare. Hellish and unsettling.
Thank you anna ghoul for the heads up on this one.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Angel, 1984 - ★★★½
item.description:
This was better than the synopsis made it sound.

Angel is a very 80s exploration thriller, with healthy but not overwhelming doses of grime and sleaze.
An eccentric cast of characters, including master of standing and walking Rory Calhoun as a washed up film cowboy, add a bit of colour and charm to the goings on, as the body count rises.

You can tell the killer is a nasty piece of work from the downright disturbing way they eat an egg.

The film doesn't demonise sex workers, which is always a bonus.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Amityville 1992: It's About Time, 1992 - ★★★½
item.description:
I had an absolute hoot watching this.

A haunted clock leads to hijinks, body horror, weird time stuff, and blood all over the place.
As if that wasn't enough people say the film's tagline "it's about time" a couple of times.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: The Theatre Bizarre, 2011 - ★★½
item.description:
As is the nature of horror anthologies, The Theatre Bizarre is a mixed bag.
Unfortunately it's also a bag which, upon getting past the knot holding it closed, in this case a framing sequence starring Udo Kier as a rather creepy doll, reveals that the first content of the bag is a rancid shite in the shape of a sequence by Richard Stanley.

With the gimmick of the film being that it takes inspiration from the Grand Guignol it's no surprise that most sequences go heavy on the blood, violence, shock and gore. There's some nice effects, Tom Savini has a segment so no prizes for guessing which part has the best effects, but nothing sticks in the mind long after watching.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Cemetery of Terror, 1985 - ★★★★
item.description:
Throwing a load of influences and tropes into a big blender has predictably messy results, but once Cemetery of Terror got going I had a great time with it.

The pacing at the start is quite iffy, but things pick up as they go on.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Bad Match, 2017 - ★★★
item.description:
I avoid finding myself in these situations by being so unappealing that no one matches me on dating apps.

I'm not quite sure if we're supposed to sympathise with Harris, but if so then I didn't, he's a prick. Therefore it's fun to watch him suffer for his own actions. Maybe that makes me a prick too.

Good fun.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Sexcula, 1974
item.description: Some questionable decision were made this evening, the end result of which were that I watched Canuxploitation porn and that I feel obligated to log my viewing on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Death Curse of Tartu, 1966 - ★★
item.description:
Second William Grefe flick of the day as I finally break open that swanky Arrow box set.
Didn't enjoy this as much as the killer jellyfish, but I still had fun.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Sting of Death, 1966 - ★★★
item.description: I've got the jellyfish song stuck in my head and I'm not even mad.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Chokeslam, 2016 - ★★½
item.description:
Apparently you can make me watch a rom-com by:
A) Putting Amanda Crew in it
B) Making it about wrestling.

Formulaic but quite charming, I popped for Lance Storm.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Rush Week, 1989 - ★★½
item.description:
I'm from Scotland, so everything I know about the American education system I've learned from films and TV.
As I understand it, if you go went to college in the 80s you had an 80% chance of being murdered by someone with a bladed weapon, probably while they were wearing a mask. 18% of the non murdered belong to a fraternity and their only character trait is being a bully and and arsehole.

Rush Week backs up all my understanding.

It's, pardon the expression, a pretty limp and lifeless slasher, but there's some cool lighting choices that give it a distinct look.

I'm confused what the deal with the necrophilia porn photographer was.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Countess Dracula, 1971 - ★★★
item.description:
Contains a Countess? ✔️
Contains a Dracula? ✖️

Gorgeous production design as you'd expect from Hammer, gorgeous Ingrid Pitt as you'd expect from having eyes.

Curiously bloodless considering the plot is a take on Elizabeth Bathory, inventor of the bath, and bathing in blood.

Solid latter era Hammer, runs out of gas a bit towards the end.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Malibu Express, 1985 - ★★½
item.description:
Hey, my first time watching an Andy Sidaris film! As is often the case recently, it's the Bat & Spider podcasts fault.

This was enjoyable nonsense. I know it was the mid 80s, but boy were there a lot of homophobic slurs, especially since the film is incredibly camp.

Loved the internal monologue though.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Blind Woman's Curse, 1970 - ★★★½
item.description:
Continuing my jump around of Meiko Kaji's filmography.

Blind Woman's Curse is a bit of a jumble, lots of interesting bits and pieces, but they don't quite fit together. There's still a lot to enjoy though.
Meiko is of course fantastic, but a bit underutilised.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: A Trip to the Moon, 1902 - ★★★★
item.description:
"Billy Corgan, Smashing Pumpkins"
"Homer Simpson, Smiling Politely"

Watched two versions, B&W which included voice overs and narration which was a bit much, and colour, which was more enjoyable.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Death Promise, 1977 - ★★★
item.description: I'm not a big martial arts film guy, but the funky as Hell soundtrack and the anti-landlord plot got me.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Elvira's Haunted Hills, 2001 - ★★★
item.description: Look it's an hour and a half of slapstick, boob jokes, and the most terrible puns possible and I'm into it.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Game of Death, 2017 - ★★★
item.description:
See now this is why I don't play board games.
Plot, script and acting range from poor to average, but I had lots of fun watching heads explode and abusrd amounts of blood spray everywhere.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Maniac, 1963 - ★★★
item.description:
No one is good to the daughter here, but an expressionless actress makes it a bit difficult to care.

Locations are nice, cast is solid and the story has some potential, but the flat direction fails to make much of the pieces.

Decent, but pedestrian.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Pieces, 1982 - ★★★★
item.description:
Back in the olden days you had to earn your pornography, by first completing a jigsaw.

I can, and indeed have, watch Pieces every couple of months and never get bored of it.

Gloriously ridiculous half giallo/half slasher, with one of the more WTF endings around.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Blood & Flesh: The Reel Life & Ghastly Death of Al Adamson, 2019 - ★★★½
item.letterboxd:filmTitle: Blood & Flesh: The Reel Life & Ghastly Death of Al Adamson
item.description:
Solidly entertaining primer on Al Adamson, his films, life, and grisly death.
Talking heads style documentaries can be a bit hit and miss, but here the interviewees talk with an enthusiasm and fondness for Adamson that's quite charming.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: 2021 First Time Watches
item.description:
Exactly what the title says.

  • Terror Train
  • 1BR
  • U.F.O. Abduction
  • Silent Madness
  • Lights Out
  • The Curious Dr. Humpp
  • Fade to Black
  • The Invitation
  • Scooby-Doo on Zombie Island

...plus 91 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: World of Horror Challenge (2021)
item.description:
Seems like I can't say no to a Horror challenge.
I'm taking a lead from c l a i r e for this one, you can find her list here

I'll be doing this alongside my own 80 Scares Around the World ongoing attempt.

Rules:
- 52 films
- Feature at least 20 countries
- No rewatches or shorts
- The movie has to be tagged under the horror genre on letterboxd
- Write at least a few words about each film

  1. Terrified

    Argentina

  2. Next of Kin

    Australia

  3. Funny Games

    Austria

  4. Hagazussa

    Austria/Germany

  5. Lake Bodom

    Estonia/Finland

  6. Dogs Don't Wear Pants

    Finland/Latvia

  7. Knife+Heart

    France

  8. Luz

    Germany

  9. La Llorona

    Guatemala

  10. Dumplings

    Hong Kong

...plus 30 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Scott & Liam Vs. Evil
item.description:
Scott and Liam Vs. Evil is a horror film podcast.
These are the films they have covered.
Find the podcast here.

  • The Forest
  • The Hexecutioners
  • Anguish
  • Portal to Hell!!!
  • Pandemic
  • The Mind's Eye
  • Patchwork
  • Southbound
  • The Other Side of the Door
  • Baskın

...plus 236 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: 80 Scares Around the World
item.description:
I don't watch enough foreign films.
There's piles of them on Blu-Ray scattered around me, but I always pass over them for something easier to stick on and half pay attention to.
With a bit of luck, this list will hopefully force me to stop that,

For international productions I've pretty much gone with the film's language, so Italy is probably over represented. That's also because I've got a lot of Giallo etc on my shelves sitting unwatched.

There's also more than 80 films listed so I can drop things unavailable to stream etc.

Any recommendations are very welcome!

  • All the Colors of the Dark

    Italy

  • Audition

    Japan

  • Baron Blood

    Italy

  • The Beyond

    Italy

  • The Black Belly of the Tarantula

    Italy

  • A Blade in the Dark

    Italy

  • Braindead

    New Zealand

  • The Case of the Bloody Iris

    Italy

  • The Case of the Scorpion's Tail

    Italy

  • Castle of Blood

    Italy

...plus 96 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Creepy Christmas
item.description:
Christmas films, but with murders, monsters and mayhem

  • Tales from the Crypt
  • The Nightmare Before Christmas
  • A Christmas Horror Story
  • Krampus
  • Black Christmas
  • Christmas Evil
  • Gremlins
  • Silent Night, Deadly Night
  • Black Christmas
  • P2

...plus 32 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Daily Horror Hunt #29 (November 2020)
item.description:
I did Hooptober easily enough, so time for a new challenge.
Rules and original list by Kelsey

I'm starting late, attempting to go with films I've not logged before as much as I can and might end up swapping things out as I go, but wish me luck!

Trivia Version:
1. This iconic director appeared in all but 18 of his 56 films. Watch one of his films.
2. This sub-genre of horror is my favourite and got it’s name from a series of cheap paperback mystery novels that were popular in Italy. Watch a film from this sub-genre.
3. After finishing filming a certain ghostly film, this child actress died at the age of 13. Watch a film that stars someone who worked with this actress in any of her films.
4. This British production studio shares it’s name with a kind of shark. Watch a film from this studio.
5. This person opened a make-up effects school and turned down a chance to direct the film, Pet Sematary. Watch a film that he worked on either as an actor, stuntman, director, or make-up/special effects person.
6. This director, who just turned 80 in September, is most known for the genre answered in number 2 and ran for political office in Rome in 1997. Watch one of his films.
7. This streaming service recently released an original horror film shot entirely over a zoom call. Watch a film that is found on this service. If you don’t have this service then look at this list and find something that is on a service that you have access to.
8. This actor did the voice over in an iconic zombie music video. Watch a film that he starred in.
9. Robert Rodriguez had to change the color of the blood of the vampires in his film From Dusk Till Dawn to this color in order to keep the amount of gore while also keeping an R rating. Watch a film with this color in its poster.
10. This decade gave us the mobile phone, the 200th birthday of the US, the death of Elvis Presley, and introduced the break up of The Beatles. Watch a horror film from this decade.
11. This director, who also turned 80 in September, is the godfather of Steven Spielberg and has been nominated the most for Worst Director at the Razzie Awards. Watch a film he directed.
12. This popular horror movie podcast that “dissects, mutilates, dismembers, and butchers all of your favorite (aaaaand not so favorite) horror movies and other horror-related events” just came back from a year long break. Watch a film that they talked about on their show you can find a full list here.
13. This director’s film most recently won an oscar for Best Picture. Watch a film from his home country.
14. The most well known co-founder of this indie film production company is most known for his acting role in The Lord of the Rings. Watch a film produced by this company.
15. Watch a film starting with the same three words as George A. Romero’s first and most popular film.
16. This term was coined by Carol J. Clover in her 1992 book Men, Women, and Chainsaws: Gender in the Modern Horror Film. Watch a film with a character that can be categorized by this term.
17. This Halloween anthology film had many title changes before filming began including Season’s Greetings, Trick or Treat, Halloween Terrors, Jack O’ Lantern Tales, and October the 31st. Watch a film starring someone who was in this 2007 film.
18. This person hosted last month’s Horror Hunt. Watch a film he rated 4 or more stars.
19. This Italian director once said, “I am not a criminal because I make horror films. A lot of Italian genre directors are animal lovers. Mario Bava loved cats, Riccardo Freda loves horses, and Dario Argento loves himself.” Watch one of this directors films.
20. The founder and president of this film production studio was rumored to have named his company after seeing the name on a passing delivery wagon. Watch a horror film produced by this studio.
21. This director named his first heavy metal band after the Bela Lugosi film White Zombie. Watch a film he has been credited for (this includes the use of his music on a film).
22. This actor was stung by bees 26 times in his most well known role. Watch a film that he acted in.
23. This iconic film was the first to show a toilet on screen. Watch a film that has been influenced by this film.
24. This magazine started around a ‘fantasy film’ concept however when their first few issues were unsuccessful they quickly switched to exclusively horror related content. Watch a film that is on their top 300 horror list.
25. One term for this sub-genre was coined by George A. Romero to describe his film Dawn of the Dead. Watch a film from this sub-genre.
26. This Mexican director became a vegetarian for four years after watching The Texas Chainsaw Massacre. Watch a horror film recommended by him in this list.
27. This decade brought us the iPod, Blu-ray, Youtube, and most of my childhood. Watch a film from this decade.
28. In 1916, film producer Adolph Zukor put 22 actors and actresses under contract and honored each with a star on the logo of this well known film production studio. Watch a horror film produced by this studio.
29. Some rituals during this holiday used to involve finding a husband. This was done by women in the 18th century by throwing apple peels over their shoulder to see their future husband’s initials, competitively bobbing for apples from which the winner would be the first to marry, and stand in a dark room with a candle in front of a mirror to look for their future husband’s face. Watch a film featuring this holiday.
30. A lot of early films to come out of this sub-genre of horror were inspired by historical events such as the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

  1. Frenzy

    Watch a Hitchcock film.

  2. Your Vice Is a Locked Room and Only I Have the Key

    Watch a Giallo film.

  3. Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon

    Watch a horror film that stars someone who worked with Heather O'Rourke in any of her films.

  4. Let Me In

    Watch a film produced by Hammer Studios.

  5. Maniac

    Watch a film that Tom Savini worked on as either an actor, stuntman, director, or make-up/special effects person.

  6. Opera

    Dario Argento is my favourite director, and he turned 80 this year. Let's watch one of his films.

  7. The Love Witch

    Watch a film that is found on Shudder,

  8. The Raven

    Watch a film starring Vincent Price.

  9. Rosemary's Baby

    Watch a horror film with the colour green in it's poster.

  10. Strip Nude for Your Killer

    Watch a horror film from the 1970's.

...plus 20 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

My favourite "classic" horror films from 1920 to 1959.

item.title: Low Rated Horror Films That I Quite Enjoy Anyway
item.description:
Horror films with a Letterboxd rating of less than 3 that I think deserve better,

Boy that's a lot of sequels...

Suggestions welcome in the comments!

  • Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday

item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Hooptober 7: I Luciferi Ranked
item.description:
My first time partaking in Hooptober, and I'm all done.
12 rules, 33 films, what was good, what was rubbish? Come and see.

Now on to Spooktober for the rest of the month.

  1. Climax
  2. The Night of the Hunter
  3. Shaun of the Dead
  4. Demons
  5. Ringu
  6. Bride of Re-Animator
  7. The Deeper You Dig
  8. Excision
  9. Ganja & Hess
  10. The Invisible Man

...plus 23 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Spooktober 2020
item.description:
Another attempt to average a horror film of some kind a day through the month of October.
I'm running this at the same time as Hooptober 7.0 so there will likely be some crossover.

No particular criteria for films included but I have a lot of Blu Rays languishing in their shrinkwrap, so opening some of those would be nice, and it's my list so I decide what counts as horror.

  • Scare Me
  • Replace
  • Howling II: Stirba - Werewolf Bitch
  • Excision
  • The Invisible Man
  • Shaun of the Dead
  • Halloween II
  • The Witch Who Came from the Sea
  • The Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2
  • Troll 2

...plus 35 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Favorite Horror Film From Each Year of My Life
item.description:
Jumping on the bandwagon here having seen a few variations of this kind of list.

One film from each year of my life, it'll be my favourite rather than the best, because sometimes I like terrible junk more than something actually good.

Some darlings were killed, some years had little to recommend, and many were sadly predictable.

  • Alien
  • The Changeling
  • An American Werewolf in London
  • The Thing
  • Psycho II
  • Gremlins
  • Demons
  • House
  • Evil Dead II
  • The Blob

...plus 32 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Jim Connick

item.title: Hooptober 7: I Luciferi
item.description:
My first Hooptober! Let's see how well I get on with it.

Mostly trying to fill the criteria with first time watches, things I've not seen for quite a while, with a couple of old favourites tossed in. Some films may swap out as we go.

QUICK EASY RULES:

6 countries (✓ ✓ ✓✓✓ ✓ USA, Italy, France, UK, Japan, Canada)
6 decades (✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓✓✓ 50s, 60s, 70s, 80s, 90s, 00s, 10s)
7 2nd films of franchises (✓✓✓✓✓✓✓ Urban Legends: Final Cut, Zombieland: Double Tap, Bride of Re-Animator, Candyman: Farewell to the Flesh, Howling II, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2, Troll 2, Cube 2: Hypercube)
4 body horror films (✓✓✓✓✓ Shivers, Bride of Re-Animator, Replace, Excision)
2 films from this year (✓✓ Host, Scare Me)
3 disease based films (✓✓✓ Shivers, Viral, Zombieland: Double Tap)
The highest rated horror film from the 50s that you haven't seen and can access. (✓ The Night of the Hunter)
1 film that is set entirely inside one location (✓ Climax)
1 Invisible Person film (✓ Memoirs of an Invisible Man)
1 Non Dracula Hammer Film (✓ The Gorgon)
2 films with a black director or predominantly black cast or lead. (✓✓ Blacula, Ganja & Hess)
1 film with a movie theatre in it. (✓ Demons)

And 1 Tobe Hooper Films (There must ALWAYS be a Hooper film) (✓The Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2)
***FOR THOSE THAT LIKE TO DO EXTRA WORK: WATCH The Witch Who Came From the Sea (✓) and Cube 2: Hypercube

-review them all.(eek)

  • The Night of the Hunter

    USA
    50s
    The highest rated horror film from the 50s that you haven't seen and can access.

  • Bride of Re-Animator

    7 2nd films of franchises

  • House of Wax

    USA
    50s

  • Ringu

    Japan
    90s

  • Blacula

    USA
    70s
    A film with a black director or predominantly black cast or lead.

  • Memoirs of an Invisible Man

    90s
    Invisible Person film

  • The Gorgon

    Non Dracula Hammer Film

  • Demons

    Italy
    80s
    A film with a movie theater in it.

  • Session 9
  • Climax

    France
    10s
    A film that is set entirely inside one location

...plus 23 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
